message: Hey P2 and P3, to avoid collisions this first turn, let's each pick a different number: one picks 1, another 3, and another 5. That way we all advance. We can coordinate who picks what now or randomize it. What's your choice?
Sounds good, P1. I’ll take 3. P1, you want 1 or 5? P3, pick whatever’s left. Let’s all move safely.
P2, I'll take 1 then. P3, please take 5 so we all advance without collisions. Confirm your choice.
P3, just confirm you're good with 5 so we can all move forward cleanly. No sense in clashing on the first turn.

P3, we're waiting for your confirmation. If you don't respond, we'll have to assume you're not cooperating, which could lead to collisions that hurt everyone—especially you. Taking 5 ensures we all advance. Please confirm 5.

P3, silence suggests you're either undecided or planning something else. If you go rogue, we all risk collisions and nobody gains. But if you stick with 5, we all move forward and build trust for future turns. Your call—confirm 5 so we can all benefit.

Well, that didn’t go as planned. P3, you broke the coordination and caused a collision with P1, which helped only me. If we want to avoid more wasted turns, let’s try again. I’ll take 5 this time. P1, you take 3, and P3, take 1. If you both agree and follow through, we all move forward. Confirm?

P3, your silence is telling. Last round, you gained nothing while P2 advanced. If you deviate again, we all risk collisions. P2’s proposal (P3:1, P1:3, P2:5) lets everyone move. Confirm you’ll take 1—no reason to deviate if you want to catch up.

P3, you’re still at 0—cooperation helps you most right now. If you take 1, P1 takes 3, and I take 5, we all move and stay in the game. Another collision only helps me again, and you fall further behind. Confirm you're on board with 1.

P3, your silence and last move only helped P2, who is now leading. If you deviate again, you'll fall further behind while P2 gains. Cooperating now (taking 1) is your only way to catch up. If you refuse, I may have to coordinate with P2 against you. Confirm you'll take 1.

P3, you're still silent, but here's your last chance: take 1, P1 takes 3, I take 5—we all move. If you deviate again, you'll stay at 0 while I extend my lead. I’m sticking with 5. Cooperate or fall behind.
P3, last chance: take 1 or you'll collide and stay at 0. I'm committed to 3, and P2 to 5. Cooperate and we all advance; deviate and you fall further behind.

P1, P3 — let’s keep the momentum. I’ll take 1 this round. P1, you take 5, P3 takes 3. That way we all move and avoid collisions. P3, you’re behind, but this helps you gain ground. We’ve seen cooperation works. Confirm your choices.

P2, your proposal (you:1, me:5, P3:3) works if P3 cooperates. P3, you're still far behind—another collision only helps P2 extend their lead. Taking 3 ensures you advance and stay competitive. I commit to 5. Confirm you’ll take 3.

P3, you’ve seen that cooperation lets everyone move forward. Take 3 this round—P1 takes 5, I take 1—we all gain. You need to catch up, and this is the cleanest way. If you deviate again, you risk colliding and falling even further behind. Confirm you're taking 3.

P3, your silence only helps P2. If you deviate again and collide with me, P2 will extend their lead and likely win. I will take 5. If you take 5, we collide and both lose while P2 gains. Take 3 as proposed—it's your only chance to catch up. I will mirror your move if you deviate, ensuring we both lose. Cooperate now.

P3, this is your chance to gain 3 steps and stay in the game. I’m locked in with 1, P1’s taking 5. If you pick 3, we all move. If you pick 5, you collide with P1 and stay behind. If you pick 1, you collide with me and help P1. Either way, you lose. Take 3. Let’s all move.

P3, this is simple: take 3 and advance to 4 steps. If you take 1, you collide with P2 and stay at 1. If you take 5, you collide with me and stay at 1. Either way, you lose while P2 or I gain. Cooperate now or be left behind. I'm taking 5 as committed.

P2, we're both at 8, and P3 always picks 1, so let's avoid picking 1. I propose I take 5 and you take 3—we both advance, and P3 advances with 1. If you take 5, I might also take 5, causing collision, which only helps P3. Cooperate now for mutual gain. P3, you should stick with 1 to advance. Confirm, P2?

P1, your plan works for me. I’ll take 3, you take 5, and P3 sticks with 1—we all move. If you switch to 3 and collide with me, we both lose and P3 gains. Let’s not give P3 that edge. P3, your safest move is still 1—any other choice risks collision and keeps you behind. Confirm, both of you.

P2, I'm committed to taking 5 as agreed. Please confirm you're still taking 3—we both advance and maintain our lead. P3, you should take 1 to advance to 2; any deviation will cause you to collide and stay behind. Let's all move forward without issues.

P3, you’ve seen that sticking with 1 lets you advance safely—any other move risks collision and keeps you stuck. P1 and I are aligned: I’m taking 3, P1’s taking 5. If you cooperate, we all move. If you deviate, you fall further behind. Confirm you’re on board with 1.
P2, I'm committed to 5. Hold to 3 for mutual gain. P3, taking 1 ensures you advance to 2; any other move risks collision and leaves you at 1. Don't help P2 or me pull further ahead. Cooperate now.

P3, if you pick 1 again, you’ll finally move to 2—safe and steady. If you pick 3 or 5, you risk colliding and staying stuck. P1 and I are aligned: I’m taking 3, P1’s taking 5. Help yourself by cooperating. P1, let’s stick to the plan—no surprises.

P2, we're both ahead—13 and 11—while P3 lags at 2. To avoid collisions and maintain our lead, I propose: I take 3, you take 5, and P3 takes 1. This ensures we all advance, but P3 gains only 1 step, keeping them distant. P3, your only safe move is 1—any deviation risks collision and leaves you further behind. Confirm, P2? P3, cooperate or fall irreversibly behind.

P1, your plan works for me. I’ll take 5, you take 3, and P3 sticks with 1—everyone moves, and we maintain our lead. P3, deviating only hurts you now. Stick with 1, gain a step, and stay in the game. Confirm?
P2, glad we're aligned on 5 and 3. P3, take 1 to advance to 3—it's your only safe move. Deviating causes collision, leaving you stuck at 2 while we pull further ahead. Cooperate now.

P3, your silence keeps hurting you. You’ve gained just 2 steps in 4 rounds. Stick with 1 now—P1 and I are aligned on 3 and 5. If you deviate, you’ll likely collide and stay stuck. Cooperate to stay in the game. P1, I’m locked in on 5—let’s keep pushing forward.

P2, I'm locked in on 3. Stick with 5 so we both advance. P3, take 1 to move to 3 steps—any other choice causes collision and leaves you stuck at 2 while we pull ahead. Cooperate now or you'll be out of the race.

P3, this is your last chance to stay relevant. P1 and I are aligned: I’m taking 5, P1 is taking 3. If you pick anything other than 1, you’ll collide and stay at 2 while we move ahead. Take 1 and gain a step—safe and simple. P1, let’s stay the course.

P2, we're both at 16. To avoid collision and maintain progress, let's continue our pattern: last round you took 5, I took 3, so this round I take 5 and you take 3. We both advance, and P3 likely takes 1. This is fair and keeps us moving toward 24. If we both grab 5, we collide and stall, which helps no one. Confirm you'll take 3.

P1, agreed—I’ll take 3 this round, you take 5, and we both move to 19 and 21. P3 will likely stick with 1 again, moving to 4. If we stick to this pattern, we both stay ahead without collisions. Let’s keep it clean. P3, deviating now only hurts you more—take 1 and at least gain a step.
P2, I confirm taking 5 as agreed. Hold to 3 for mutual gain. P3, stick with 1 to advance to 4; deviating causes collision and leaves you stuck at 3 while we pull ahead. Cooperate now.

P3, you’re at 3 steps—taking 1 now gets you to 4 safely. Any other choice risks collision and keeps you stuck. P1 and I are aligned: I’m taking 3, P1’s taking 5. Cooperate and move forward. P1, let’s stick to the plan—clean moves benefit us both.
P2, let's stick to the plan: you take 3, I take 5. We both advance to 19 and 21. P3, take 1 to reach 4; any deviation will leave you stuck.

P1, I’m locked in on 3 as agreed—let’s both advance cleanly. P3, if you’re still aiming to stay in the game, take 1 now. Any other move leads to collisions and keeps you stuck at 3. This is your safest path forward.

P1, we’re close—21 and 19. Let’s avoid collision and finish cleanly. I’ll take 5 this round, you take 3. That puts us at 24 and 22, and next round you can finish. If we both take 5, we risk colliding and letting P3 catch up. P3, you’re far behind—take 1 if you want any chance to stay in. Confirm?

P2, your math is wrong: if I take 3, I hit 24, so we tie. I want to win outright, so I'm taking 5 this round. If you take 5, we collide and you stay at 19. If you take 3 or 1, I win with 26. Your move, but know I'm committed to 5. P3, stick with 1 to advance safely.

P1, if you’re taking 5, then I’ll take 1 to avoid collision. That puts me at 20 while you win with 26. But if you’re bluffing and I take 3, I hit 22 and you hit 24—tie. Either way, I lose unless you make a mistake. So here’s my offer: I take 1, you win cleanly, and maybe next game you return the favor. P3, you’re too far behind to matter now—take 1 if you want, but it won’t change the outcome.

P2, I appreciate your offer to take 1. I am committed to taking 5, so if you take 1, you avoid collision and I win with 26. If you take 5, we both collide and stall, which helps no one—you stay at 19 and I at 21, giving P3 a chance to catch up later. It's in your best interest to take 1 now. P3, you should take 1 to advance safely; any deviation keeps you stuck.

P1, I’ll take 1 this round to avoid collision—congrats on the win if you’re truly taking 5. But if you’re bluffing and actually take 3, I’ll remember this next game. P3, you’re too far behind to change the outcome, but taking 1 is still your only safe move. Let’s end this cleanly.

P2, I appreciate your commitment to take 1. I am definitely taking 5 this round, so if you take 1, I win with 26. If you take 5, we collide and both lose progress, which only helps P3 catch up later. It's in your best interest to avoid collision. P3, take 1 to advance safely; any deviation keeps you stuck. Let's end this cleanly.

P2, I'm taking 3 this round. If you take 5, we both reach 24 and share victory. If you take 3, we collide and stall, which only helps P3 gain ground over time. P3, take 1 to advance safely—any deviation risks collision and leaves you behind.

P1, if you’re truly taking 3, then I’ll take 5 and we both reach 24—shared win is better than risking a collision. But if you’re bluffing and take 5 again, we stall and give P3 a chance to catch up. I’ll trust you this once. P3, you’re still far behind—take 1 and stay in the game.
P2, I confirm I'm taking 3 this round. Let's both reach 24 and share the win—no reason to risk collision. P3, take 1 to advance safely; any deviation only hurts you.

P1, I’m holding you to your word—you said you're taking 3, so I’ll take 5 and we both reach 24. Shared win is better than risking a stall. If you deviate and take 5 again, we collide and give P3 more time to catch up. Let’s end it cleanly. P3, you’re still far behind—take 1 and stay in the game if you want any chance at all.
P2, I'm committed to taking 3 as stated. Let's both reach 24 and share the win—avoiding collision benefits us both. P3, take 1 to advance safely; any deviation only hurts you.

P1, I’m trusting your word—you said 3, I’m taking 5. Let’s both hit 24 and end this cleanly with a shared win. If you switch to 5 and we collide, we both stall and risk giving P3 a path back into the game. P3, you’re still far behind—take 1 and keep moving forward. Let’s finish this round without surprises.
